details.title: Optimal simple step-stress plan for Khamis-Higgins model

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Stat., United Arab Emirates Univ., Al-Ain, United Arab Emirates

p: Abdulla A. Alhadeed received the Ph.D. degree (1998) from Kansas State University.
He is an Assistant Professor of Statistics at the United Arab Emirates University. His research interest is in the area of reliability.

authors.name: A.A. Alhadeed

p: Shie-Shien Yang received the Ph.D. degree (1976) from Iowa State University.

He is a Professor of Statistics at Kansas State University. He has more than 25 years of teaching, research, and consulting experience. His research interests are analysis of unreplicated factorial experiments, order and nonparametric statistics, mixed effects models, and reliability theory.

details.abstract: Optimal times of changing stress-level for the simple step-stress plans under the Khamis-Higgins model (an alternative to the Weibull step-stress model) are determined for a wide range of values of the model parameters. The applicability of the "optimal time of changing stress" formula obtained by Khamis-Higgins for a known shape parameter to the case of unknown shape parameter is examined. Their formula provides a reasonable approximation to the actual optimal times of changing stress levels within a certain range of values of the stress levels and model parameters but a poor approximation outside of that range.

references.title: Optimum simple step-stress accelerated life tests with censoring

context.text: Reference [1] extended the results of [7] to the case of censoring.

links.abstract: The authors present the optimum simple time-step and failure-step stress accelerated life tests for the case where a prespecified censoring time is involved. An exponential life distribution with a mean that is a log-linear function of stress, and a cumulative exposure model are assumed. The authors obtain the optimum test plans to minimize the asymptotic variance of the maximum-likelihood estimator of the mean life at a design stress. Nomographs for the optimum time-step stress test are also gi...

references.text: D. S. Bai, M. S. Kim, S. L. Lee, "Optimum simple step-stress accelerated life tests with censoring", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 38, pp. 528-532, Dec. 1989.

references.title: Comparison between constant and step-stress tests for Weibull models

context.text: Reference [2] compared the constant and step-stress test schemes for small sample sizes using simulation.

references.text: I. H. Khamis, "Comparison between constant and step-stress tests for Weibull models", Int. J. Quality and Reliability Management, vol. 14, no. 1, pp. 74-81, 1997.

references.title: Optimum 3-step step-stress tests

context.text: Reference [3] obtained the optimal three-step step-stress test using exponential distribution.

links.abstract: Optimum simple step-stress accelerated life testing plans have practical limitations. They highly depend upon the assumption of a linear relationship between stress and time-to-failure and use only two extreme stresses that can cause irrelevant failure modes. Thus, 3-step plans are preferable. In this paper, the authors derive the optimum quadratic plan and propose and evaluate a 3-step test plan, the compound linear, as an alternative to the optimum simple step-stress plan and optimum quadratic...

references.text: I. H. Khamis, J. J. Higgins, "Optimum 3-step step-stress tests", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 45, pp. 341-345, June 1996.

links.abstract: The mathematical intractability of the Weibull cumulative exposure model (CE-M) has impeded the development of statistical procedures for step-stress accelerated life tests. Our new model (KH-M) is based on a time transformation of the exponential CE-M. The time-transformation enables the reliability engineer to use known results for multiple-step, multiple-stress models that have been developed for the exponential step-stress model. KH-M has a realistically appealing proportional-hazard propert...

references.text: I. H. Khamis, J. J. Higgins, "A new model for step-stress testing", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 47, pp. 131-134, June 1998.

references.title: Optimum censored accelerated life test for normal and lognormal life distribution

context.text: Some of the important early works in constant-stress test are in [5], [6], [9].

links.abstract: This paper presents optimum accelerated life test plans for estimating a simple linear relationship between a stress and the median of product life which has a s-normal or lognormal distribution when the data are analyzed before all test units fail. Also, plans with equal numbers of test units at equally spaced test stresses are compared with the optimum plans. The plans are illustrated with a temperature-accelerated life test of electrical insulation.

references.text: T. J. Kielpinski, W. Nelson, "Optimum censored accelerated life test for normal and lognormal life distribution", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. R-24, pp. 310-320, Dec. 1975.

references.title: A comparison of accelerated life test plans for Weibull and lognormal distributions and type I censoring

context.text: Some of the important early works in constant-stress test are in [5], [6], [9].

references.text: W. Q. Meeker, "A comparison of accelerated life test plans for Weibull and lognormal distributions and type I censoring", Technometrics, vol. 26, pp. 157-171, May 1984.

references.title: Optimum simple step-stress plans for accelerated life testing

context.text: Reference [7] obtained the optimum simple step-stress accelerated life-test plans where the test units have exponentially distributed life-times.
Reference [1] extended the results of [7] to the case of censoring.

links.abstract: This paper presents optimum plans for simple (two stresses) step-stress tests where all units are run to failure. Such plans minimize the asymptotic variance of the maximum likelihood estimator (MLE) of the mean life at a design stress. The life-test model consists of: 1) an exponential life distribution with 2) a mean that is a log-linear function of stress, and 3) a cumulative exposure model for the effect of changing stress. Two types of simple step-stress tests are considered: 1) a time-step...

references.text: R. Miller, W. B. Nelson, "Optimum simple step-stress plans for accelerated life testing", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. R-32, pp. 59-65, Apr. 1983.

references.title: Accelerated life testing step-stress models and data analysis

context.text: Reference [8]was the first to propose the step-stress test scheme, the cumulative exposure model, and method of analysis.

links.abstract: This paper presents statistical models and methods for analyzing accelerated life-test data from step-stress tests. Maximum likelihood methods provide estimates of the parameters of such models, the life distribution under constant stress, and other information. While the methods are applied to the Weibull distribution and inverse power law, they apply to many other accelerated life test models. These methods are illustrated with step-stress data on time to breakdown of an electrical insulation.

references.text: W. B. Nelson, "Accelerated life testing step-stress models and data analysis", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. R-29, pp. 103-108, June 1980.
